update.description:
This is a first part of the procedure to update homebrew formulae as a consequence of the `release.py` script. Currently we create and upload tarballs. This PR also computes a sha256 of the tarball and passes it as a parameter to the jenkins jobs.

Hopefully it won't break existing jobs to receive an unexpected parameter.

After this PR, we should create a new jenkins job that takes 3 parameters:

* package name (with major revision if applicable, ie `sdformat3`)
* tarball URI
* tarball sha256

That jenkins job should do the following:

* `git clone https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation`
* modify the requested formula
* commit and push to a fork / branch
* create a pull request against `osrf/homebrew-simulation`

I think that would be a good start.
update.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

pullrequest.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

content.raw:
To finish with this, I've made some changes:

 * [Implement the DSL job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/_dsl_core/) to create the [jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_pull_request_updater/)
 * Refactor the token class for releasing
 * Include the call in release.py

[A testing run with an unknown package](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_pull_request_updater/7/console) failed as expected.
content.html:
To finish with this, I've made some changes:

  • Implement the DSL job to create the jenkins job
  • Refactor the token class for releasing
  • Include the call in release.py

A testing run with an unknown package failed as expected.

content.raw:
I figured out how to solve the different problems and the first successful testing run is ready:

 * http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/_test_brew_pullrequest/17/
 * which generates the following pull request: https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/61

We need to setup two types of authentication: one for using the git command (ssh keys) and another for using hub (token).
content.html:
I figured out how to solve the different problems and the first successful testing run is ready:

  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/_test_brew_pullrequest/17/
  • which generates the following pull request: https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/61

We need to setup two types of authentication: one for using the git command (ssh keys) and another for using hub (token).

content.raw:
I'm using sdformat3 against sdformat2 (so get something different) to perform the test: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/_test_brew_pullrequest/6/console. It is failing with:

```
 ! [remote rejected] sdformat2_3.6.1 -> sdformat2_3.6.1 (shallow update not allowed)
```

Note that in the output we have: 
```
Hi osrfbuild! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.
```
content.html:
I'm using sdformat3 against sdformat2 (so get something different) to perform the test: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/_test_brew_pullrequest/6/console. It is failing with:

 ! [remote rejected] sdformat2_3.6.1 -> sdformat2_3.6.1 (shallow update not allowed)

Note that in the output we have: 

Hi osrfbuild! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

content.raw:
Running the script on my local machine from `/tmp` just created a pull request!

* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/59/files

~~~
export PACKAGE_ALIAS=gazebo6
export SOURCE_TARBALL_URI=http://gazebosim.org/distributions/gazebo/releases/gazebo-6.5.1.tar.bz2
export VERSION=6.5.1
bash ${RELEASE-TOOLS}/jenkins-scripts/lib/homebrew_formula_pullrequest.bash
~~~
content.html:
Running the script on my local machine from /tmp just created a pull request!

  • https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/59/files
export PACKAGE_ALIAS=gazebo6
export SOURCE_TARBALL_URI=http://gazebosim.org/distributions/gazebo/releases/gazebo-6.5.1.tar.bz2
export VERSION=6.5.1
bash ${RELEASE-TOOLS}/jenkins-scripts/lib/homebrew_formula_pullrequest.bash

This is a first part of the procedure to update homebrew formulae as a consequence of the `release.py` script. Currently we create and upload tarballs. This PR also computes a sha256 of the tarball and passes it as a parameter to the jenkins jobs.

Hopefully it won't break existing jobs to receive an unexpected parameter.

After this PR, we should create a new jenkins job that takes 3 parameters:

* package name (with major revision if applicable, ie `sdformat3`)
* tarball URI
* tarball sha256

That jenkins job should do the following:

* `git clone https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation`
* modify the requested formula
* commit and push to a fork / branch
* create a pull request against `osrf/homebrew-simulation`

I think that would be a good start.

content.raw:
Progress! I've created an `osrfbuild` github user with a fork of the `osrf/simulation` tap. I've also updated the script to push to that fork, download the [hub](https://github.com/github/hub) command and try to create a pull request.

We would still need to figure out github authentication from jenkins nodes.
content.html:
Progress! I've created an osrfbuild github user with a fork of the osrf/simulation tap. I've also updated the script to push to that fork, download the hub command and try to create a pull request.

We would still need to figure out github authentication from jenkins nodes.

pull_request.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

pullrequest.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

content.raw:
I've been tinkering with bottles, and I believe these need to be built in a clean environment so you don't accidentally find optional dependencies (like dartsim) and have unresolved symbols at runtime. I'm currently using a virtual machine. It would be nice to be able to use our jenkins nodes as well.

I've discovered two cool `brew` commands:

~~~
# this will pull and commit the code in a specified pull request
brew pull https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/52
~~~

~~~
# if you want to build a bottle in our tap:
# it won't build though if the pull request has already been merged
# also, I had trouble using the `--keep-old` option, since it tries to insert a bintray `root_url`
brew test-bot \
  --tap=osrf/simulation \
  --bottle \
  --ci-pr \
  --verbose \
  https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/52
~~~

I used this to build a bottle for gazebo 6.4.0 and it seems to work.
content.html:
I've been tinkering with bottles, and I believe these need to be built in a clean environment so you don't accidentally find optional dependencies (like dartsim) and have unresolved symbols at runtime. I'm currently using a virtual machine. It would be nice to be able to use our jenkins nodes as well.

I've discovered two cool brew commands:

# this will pull and commit the code in a specified pull request
brew pull https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/52

# if you want to build a bottle in our tap:
# it won't build though if the pull request has already been merged
# also, I had trouble using the `--keep-old` option, since it tries to insert a bintray `root_url`
brew test-bot \
  --tap=osrf/simulation \
  --bottle \
  --ci-pr \
  --verbose \
  https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/52

I used this to build a bottle for gazebo 6.4.0 and it seems to work.

* package name (with major revision if applicable, ie `sdformat3`)
* tarball URI
* tarball sha256

That jenkins job should do the following:

* `git clone https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation`
* modify the requested formula
* commit and push to a fork / branch
* create a pull request against `osrf/homebrew-simulation`

I think that would be a good start.

content.raw:
I chose linuxbrew so we could use our linux jenkins nodes. I suppose we could try to write a platform-independent script that would work on osx as well, but I decided to focus on this for now.

Currently it just modifies a formula. We still need to commit, push, and create a pull request.
content.html:
I chose linuxbrew so we could use our linux jenkins nodes. I suppose we could try to write a platform-independent script that would work on osx as well, but I decided to focus on this for now.

Currently it just modifies a formula. We still need to commit, push, and create a pull request.

pull_request.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

pullrequest.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

content.raw:
I just started tinkering with a script for modifying homebrew formulae in response to environment variables of `PACKAGE_ALIAS`, `SOURCE_TARBALL_URI`, and `SOURCE_TARBALL_SHA`

It makes use of [linuxbrew](https://github.com/Homebrew/linuxbrew), which provides a nice way to get the tap, locate files and also use Aliases (see [Aliases folder in homebrew-simulation](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/tree/master/Aliases)) to assist with different naming schemes. I also slightly abuse the `brew irb` interface to programmatically access the path, stable url and checksum of a given formula, which I use for targeted search/replace with sed/grep.
content.html:
I just started tinkering with a script for modifying homebrew formulae in response to environment variables of PACKAGE_ALIAS, SOURCE_TARBALL_URI, and SOURCE_TARBALL_SHA

It makes use of linuxbrew, which provides a nice way to get the tap, locate files and also use Aliases (see Aliases folder in homebrew-simulation) to assist with different naming schemes. I also slightly abuse the brew irb interface to programmatically access the path, stable url and checksum of a given formula, which I use for targeted search/replace with sed/grep.

pull_request.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

pullrequest.title: Compute sha256 for generated tarballs and pass to jenkins jobs

content.raw:
I figured it was most secure to compute the shasum at the time of creating the tarball in case there were any errors during uploading. So I like trying to provide it if possible.

Maybe the jobs that need a shasum can download the tarball and recompute if it is not supplied? If it is wrong the job should abort.
content.html:
I figured it was most secure to compute the shasum at the time of creating the tarball in case there were any errors during uploading. So I like trying to provide it if possible.

Maybe the jobs that need a shasum can download the tarball and recompute if it is not supplied? If it is wrong the job should abort.
